div.p: I. V. Thursday.

Mr. Steinhofer is a German Clergyman, who came to solicit contributions for a German Church at Baltimore— Captain Norman an old acquaintance of St. Petersburg was also here. He resides at Baltimore, and came here he said to a sick Son— The Son was some time since summoned here as a witness upon questions now before the Senate—in relation to the Affairs of the late Purser Timberlake— He was on board the ship; and an assistant or clerk to him. He now resides at New-York, and after attending here as summoned fell sick, and has been very dangerously ill but is recovering— Mr Johnson was here complaining of a return of his ill health for which he thinks of embarking again for France— The 8th. Book of the familiar Epistles consists of 17 Letters from Marcus Coelius Rufus to Cicero. They seem to be strangely misplaced; for about half the second Book consists of Letters from Cicero to him. These Letters however are precious—they paint the character of the man and of the age— They are written in a very good Style; reporting from Rome to Cicero in Cilicia, the principal proceedings of the Senate, and marking distinctly the approaches to the civil War. In the first Letter speaking of Pompey he says, “write me what he said to you, and what he wished, for he is used to say one thing and intend another; though he has no skill to conceal his wishes— In another Letter he says that Caesar makes it his object to obtain at any cost the friendship of the lowest class of People, and that he holds Curio in great contempt— Yet Curio was afterwards the most devoted of his Creatures— Coelius himself was a great time server.— He succeeded in an election as Edile against a competitor named Hirrus, who he says after his defeat played the good citizen and made speeches against Caesar— Coelius himself did much the same— In the 14th. Letter he lays down the broad principle, that in domestic dissensions, as long as they are disputed by argument, a man should take the most virtuous Life, but when it comes to fighting, the strongest— This was his reason for siding with Caesar—yet in the last Letter of the book he casts off the party of Caesar and seems greatly inclined to adopt the other.
2. V. Friday.

Mr Maury of the navy Department came and introduced his Cousin from the State of Tennessee— Mr Saltonstall brought me a Letter of Introduction from Mr Edward Everett, and one to him from Mr Charles Aug. Davis of New-York— Mr Saltonstall has formed a Settlement in the Island of Cuba, and has obtained in the name of another person a Spanish subject, a Steamboat privilege upon one of the Rivers of the Island. But wishing to hold it in his own name, he is about returning to the Island with the intention
of becoming a Spanish subject by taking out Letters of Naturalization. And he wished to obtain Letters of introduction from me to the Governor and Captain General Vives who he was informed entertained great Respect for me— I declined giving such Letters— First, because Mr Saltonstall is a total Stranger to me—recommended by Mr Everett only upon the recommendation of Mr Davis— Secondly, because Mr Saltonstall proposes to become a Spanish Subjects, and has concerns of private interest, for which he wishes to secure the favour of the Governor and Captain General— How this may be viewed by him, I do not know, and a recommendation of the man might involve me in some responsibility for his projects— The facility with which men of character and consideration in this Country give recommendations leads to pernicious consequences— When the nomination of Henry Lee some days since was rejected unanimously by the Senate on account of the surpassing infamy of his character, the Telegraph put the disgrace of the appointment, upon the recommendation of Chief Justice Marshall and Judge M’lean— Pudet haec opprobria non potuisse refelli.— Some of their friends were startled, and finally took distinctions, alledging that they gave not recommendations but merely certificates of Talents— Good nature, unwillingness to refuse, and the repute of a kind and condescending disposition, are motives of such strong prevailment, that men of high reputation sign recommendations for all sorts of persons and things—for aspirants to Office; for Epic Poems, Spelling-books, Quack Medicines, Razor Straps and perpetual motions. I told Mr Saltonstall that my acquaintance with General Vivés had been altogether official, and that I had never ventured to give any person an introduction to him, but in his Official character and as connected with public affairs—regretting that I could not depart from this principle though wishing him success in his undertaking. Mr Fendall called and sat with me an hour— He mentioned the splendid Speech of Mr Clayton, the New Senator from Delaware, some of the Doctrines of which I think not sound, but which taken altogether is one of the most powerful and eloquent Orations ever delivered in either of the Hall’s of Congress— I received from Jos. Blunt, three half sheets of my chapters upon Russia, Turkey and Greece, which I revised, and answered him with a list of errata—
3. V. Saturday.

Morning visit from Dr Croghan, from Kentucky, a brother of Mrs Jesup who is our Neighbour. Then from Mr Lawless of Missouri who has preferred a complaint to the House of Representatives against the Judge of the District Court of the United States, in that State Peck— The judiciary Committee of the House, have reported, Lawless says unanimously, that the judge should be impeached. The judge himself is here, and Mr Lawless supposes, that the impeachment will be tried at this Session of Congress— Mr Torlade the Chargé d’Affaires of Don Miguel, king de facto of Portugal, was here—and told me he had received la triste nouvelle, of the death of the Queen Mother. This woman is a Sister of Ferdinand of Spain and had the reputation of a fury— She conspired to dethrone the king her husband; and is understood to have been the heart and Soul of the Counter-revolution, and the instigatress of Miguel in all his abominations. I had thought the account of her death by no
means a triste nouvelle. Mr Torlade said she was a woman of very energetic character, extremely attached to her friends—mais aussi, very vehement in her hatred— He then spoke of the National Sentiment of the Portuguese, and considered it as settling the title of Don Miguel to the Crown—for, said he, speculate as we may upon this subject we always must return to that eternal and inextinguishable principle the Sovereignty of the People. Mr Torlade said much also of his controversy with Mr Barroso Pereira, for the Archives of the Portuguese Legation— The State Court in Philadelphia decided that Mr Barroso having once enjoyed the immunities of a foreign Minister the tribunals of this Country could not deprive him of them; nor coerce him to surrender the Archives— Mr Torlade is sorely afflicted with this decision, and intends to have the question retried by the Supreme Court of the United States. It is among the whimsical results in the application of anomalous principles, that here is a foreign Minister who cannot obtain possession of the Archives of his Legation precisely because he is not amenable to the jurisdiction of the Country. The diplomatic privilege is arrayed against itself, and while it shelters Mr Barroso, leaves Torlade, helpless and impotent— As Barroso was of the Constitutional party and Torlade is the Representative of Miguel, our Judges, I have no doubt were the readier to avail themselves of the Jus Gentium in favour of the liberal party, and against the detested Rule of Don Miguel. Mrs Dickenson, and Mrs B. O. Tayloe paid visits to the Ladies.— My leisure is again oppressive and I am not well advised how to employ it.
4. V. Sunday.

Heard Mr Campbell, this morning from Matthew 13.17 “If ye know these things, happy are ye if ye do them” and in the Evening from Matthew 13.3–8. “And he spake many things unto them in parables, saying, Behold, a sower went forth to sow,[”] &c—the parable of the Sower— The doctrine drawn from this parable by Mr Campbell, was rather harsh— It is the general character of Presbyterian preaching to terrify rather than to allure— This does not altogether suit my temper. Believing in the goodness and Mercy of the Creator, I disbelieve those who represent him as existing only to hurl thunder— Nothing but Thunder. Nor do I think the moral character improved by tempering the mind to action under the perpetual terror of the scourge—incredulus Odi— The system is much easier for a preacher than that of operating either by argument or persuasion, and its tendency is to stiffen the influence of the preacher into Authority. The Negro Slave dreads the Overseer who holds the whip, more than the Master in whose name it is brandished— I listen with pleasure to expositions of the goodness and mercy of God, and delight in the 136th Psalm— Exhortations to righteousness and truth, brotherly kindness and charity have more prevailment over me, than unceasing denunciations of vengeance and punishment— There are however denominations of Christians who hold different opinions, and insist upon being doomed weekly, by their Pastors to the infernal Regions, and such are perhaps the Major part of Mr Campbell’s Auditors. After the morning Service, Mr Hodges a Member of the House of Representatives introduced
Mr Deberry, also a Member, and from the State of North-Carolina, where, he said he was a friend of the last Administration, and was upon the Electoral ticket which failed— In the Evening Coll. Dwight called, with Judge Wright who is employed on the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal; Mr De Graff who was a member of the House of Representatives from New-York State in the last Congress, and a Mr Legate, also from New-York— I read part of an Article in the Quarterly Review, for July 1828. upon Psalmody; and some pages of Sale’s Preliminary Discourse, before his Translation of the Koran— I find this Book exceedingly difficult to read—chiefly on account of its tediousness— Sale himself both in the Preliminary Discourse and in the Notes on the Koran, shews himself profoundly learned in Arabic Religious Literature and History; and also versed in Jewish and Christian Theology— But he is manifestly partial to the impostor, and had read so much Arabic reverential and panegyrical Commentary upon the spurious Apostle, and his Book that he was infected by the constant handling of the matter— The book itself is such a chaotic jumble of balderdash that its success presents the most astonishing monument of human imbecility, recorded in the history of the species.
5. IV: Monday. Sun rose.

Went out upon my walk soon after four, and returned to see the Sun rise— Mrs Handy came to ask a loan of money for her husband, which I necessarily declined. Mr Whittlesey introduced his Son, a young man who is about to commence business, and is going to New-York to purchase a Stock of goods— Judge Spencer in the Evening introduced Mr Gregory of Albany, as an old revolutionary Officer and a neighbour of Mr Sanford the Senator, of whose politics and family they spoke freely— Sanford married for his third wife Mary Buchanan, who they say is very much respected in Albany— Sanford was a friend of the late Administration; and personally friendly to me, till he found it prudent to desert me; and then he silently ratted— His neighbours understand his character well; and I told them he would never be a martyr for any thing. At present his vote in the Senate counts one for Martin Van Buren, and a cypher for every thing else. The 9th. Book of the familiar Epistles contains 8 Letters to Marcus Tenentius Varro, 5 to Dolabella, and 1 from him to Cicero, and 12 to Lucius Papirius Paetus— The Letters to Varro are all expositions of the reasons for the course of Life which Cicero pursued, during the civil Wars, after the Battle of Pharsalia— It was that of submission to the power of Caesar—retirement into the Country; and devotion of all his time to Literature and philosophy— The 6th Letter is the most particular and impressive— It is one thing says Cicero, to endure what we cannot help, and another to approve what should be blamed— The extremest of all evils is the victory of a civil War— We live in a convulsed Republic—who can deny it? but let those look to that who have no resources provided for every condition of life— But if our Country cannot or will not command our services, who shall deny us the privilege of resorting to that course of life which many learned men, perhaps not correctly, but yet many have thought preferable even to the public service— In the next Letter he says he makes it a frequent practice to sup with the persons most in power— And with the next he sends to Varro his four Books of Academic Questions— The Letter from Dolabella is an earnest intreaty to Cicero, either to take the part of Caesar in the civil War; or else to take no part in it, and to withdraw to Athens, or some
other place of retirement, till the War is over— The Letters to Dolabella are written at some distance of time from each other— One immediately after the death of Tullia—the last, after the Death of Caesar— Dolabella being Consul—whom he extols to the skies for destroying an Altar, erected to Caesar— The Letters to Paetus are remarkable for a vein of pleasantry running through them all— Paetus was himself a joker— And Cicero says that the old Romans had more Attic Salt than the Athenians themselves. And as for himself Ego autem mirifice capior facetiis— In the same Letter replying to one in which Paetus had urged him to resume his share in the transaction of public affairs, he says—you talk of Catulus and those times—but how different! Then, I was seated upon deck, and held the helm—now there is scarcely room in the hold. Do you think there would be one Senatus consultum the less, if I were at Naples? Even when I am at Rome, and walk the forum, the decrees of the Senate are all written at the house of my friend your admirer— And when it comes in to his head, my name is used for writing them: and I hear of a Senatus consultum, proclaimed in Armenia or Syria, said to have passed upon my Motion, when I had never heard a word of it before— Do not think I am joking. But be assured I have received Letters from remote kings, thanking me for their royal titles confirmed upon them at my proposition, when so far from calling them kings: I knew not so much as their existence— There were distributions of Lands made to the Soldiers of Caesar— Paetus was fearful that his Lands would be taken for that purpose, and wrote to enquire of Cicero, if there was danger— The answer is not positive— He refers Paetus to his friend Balbus, much better acquainted with Caesar’s intentions than he, and who he says, drunk or sober, will tell him— Arms will always give the Law— And if Caesar himself wished a Republic as it ought to be, he could not make it, entangled as he is with so many associates.— Therefore my friend apply your heart to wisdom; pray for the best—expect the worst and be prepared for whatever may happen.— In the next Letter he tells Paetus that like Dionysius of Syracuse he has opened a school at . . . to which he invites him—and adds that he sups upon Peacocks— In the 20th. he gives an account of his daily course of life— In the 21st. observations upon the epistolary Style— In the 22d. a dissertation upon decency of language— In the 24th. written after the death of Caesar, he says he devotes his Nights and days to the service and Salvation of the Republic. The 25th. and 26th. Letters appear to be of an earlier date.
6. V. Tuesday.

Captain Conner came to converse with me again upon his discovery of the Longitude; shewed me several of the diagrams, by which he makes his demonstration, and asked my advice what he should do to get something for it— I recommended to him to apply to the Secretary of the Navy, or the Commissioners of the Navy-board; but he said he had already communicated to them his method of planking ships, which they had adopted but allowed him nothing for it. He still insists that the Hulls of all our line of battle ships upon the stocks, are honey-combs—particularly the enormous ship at Philadelphia— Timbers, all rotten. He was quite inclined to obtain the premium offered by the British Parliament for the discovery of the Longitude, which he told me was sixty thousand Pounds Sterling.
Mr Bell and Mr Burnet, Senators from New-Hampshire and Ohio paid me a morning visit— They said Mr White, Senator from Tennessee, was making a Speech in Support of a Bill, which he has reported from a Committee, for exporting the Southern Indians to the Territory West of Arkansas. Mr White, they said, usually made his speeches three times over. He had been speaking about three quarters of an hour, and was about commencing his first repetition, when they thought they might indulge themselves with a walk, and return without losing any thing. These gentlemen think that the Editorial nominations now before the Senate, that is the writers and publishers of scurrilous newspapers electioneering Skunks, of whom there are about fifty appointed to Office, and perhaps twenty of them now in nomination, before the Senate, will be rejected. But they will all or nearly all pass—one or two may fail. General Jackson rules by his personal popularity, which his partizans in the Senate dare not encounter, by opposing any thing that he does, and while that popularity shall last, his majorities in both houses of Congress will stand by him for good or evil. It has totally broken down in the Senate, both the Esprit de Corps, and the combination against the Executive, which from the last Session of Mr Jefferson’s Administration, had presided in many of their deliberations, and governed many of their decisions. And indeed it produced so many pernicious consequences, that I sincerely believe the subserviency of these days less mischievous— In the moral Government of the world one vice is oftener punished by another, than either is reformed by virtue— A servile Senate is contemptible— A factious one is more dangerous— Mr Seymour the Senator from Vermont called in the Evening, with his brother who is a Canal Commissioner in the State of New-York— Mr De Graff and a Mr Ledger also of New-York. I received three half-sheets of Letter-press from Joseph Blunt; which I revised, and wrote to him briefly. Mrs Adams spent the Evening with her brother; and I went to his house and walked home with her.
7. IV:30. Wednesday.

Mr Ruggles and Mr Hendricks, Senators from Ohio and Indiana, introduced Mr Yarnull and Mr Wilson— Besides my Morning walk, I rode about an hour before dinner; and am convinced that this is the best of all Medicines for my health, though always attended with great danger in the taking. Mrs Frye dined with us, and Mr Frye was here in the Evening but I did not know it. In the tenth Book of the familiar Epistles there are 24 Letters of Correspondence between Cicero and Lucius Munatius Plancus. 2 to Furnius. 1 to Lepidus 1 to Trebonius. 1. to Ampius. 1. from Galba to Cicero. 3. from Asinius Pollio. 1 from Lepidus to Cicero, and 1. from Lepidus to the Senate and People— These Letters were all written in the last year of Cicero’s Life—while the War was waging with Antony. Plancus had been one of the favourites of Julius Caesar, who had bestowed a large sum of money upon him. After the Death of Caesar, he was Praetor in Transalpine Gaul, where he commanded a large army. He was designated Consul with Decimus Brutus, the year after Hirtius and Pansa. He was one of the Generals upon whom they relied to put down the rebellion of Antony, and in this Correspondence, he pledges himself in his Letters to the Senate and to Cicero that he will inflexibly maintain the cause of the Country— Notwithstanding all which he was treacherous— He first united his troops with those of Lepidus, who acted the same double dealing part; and they both joined Antony, after he had been beaten
at Mutina. Lepidus first and Plancus afterwards— There is a long Letter from Plancus to the Senate, full of Apologies and professions of patriotism—several to Cicero, charging Lepidus with perfidy, and calling for reinforcements; and one in which he throws all the blame of Antony’s escape, after the battle at Mutina, upon Octavius Caesar— He says—that Antony now lives, that Lepidus is with him, that they have no despicable armies—their hopes—their daring, are all attributable to young Caesar— And he concludes by saying that if Caesar yet will do his duty or if the African Legions will speedily come, the Republic will be safe in that quarter. It was but a few days after that the second Triumvirate was formed, and Plancus betrayed his Country like the rest— The Letter to Trebonius, relates to him the Meeting of the Senate on the 19th. of December, when he delivered the third Philippic— It was written however sometime afterwards for it mentions the death of Servius Sulpicius, Trebonius himself was shortly afterwards treacherously murdered at Smyrna by Dolabella. Pollio was a Prefect in Spain, by the appointment of Julius Caesar. But he declares his devotion to the Country, and that from his experience of the miseries of absolute power, he never would consent to such a state of things again— His third Letter gives an account of the Battles at Mutina, where the Consuls Hirtius and Pansa were both killed. The Letter from Lepidus to Cicero, promises stoutly to defend the Republic against Antony, and then comes the Letter to the Senate, protesting by all the Gods that he had been compelled by a mutiny of his own army to join with Antony
8. IV.30. Thursday.

Returning this morning from my walk, I was joined by Major Luckett of Louisville Kentucky, an old acquaintance who was here five or six years since, very earnest in search of a place, which I believe he did not then succeed in obtaining. He asked me this morning which was the earliest riser—himself or me. I believed he must bear that palm— He said he had then been two-hours up— I said I had been up little more than one hour. I asked him how long he proposed to stay here— He did not know, two or three months at least— He was in hopes of getting a place. He had not meddled much with Politics, but he was personally acquainted with General Jackson; and Mr. Barry and Coll. R. M. Johnson were his friends— He asked me whether the Consuls to the Barbary Powers had Salaries—to what amount—and how many of them there were— My answer to this question he took a paper and pencil from his pocket, and marked down, and intimated that I had omitted Syracuse from the list. He then enquired about the Consulate at London, but I told him that Office was filled— He asked if I thought the Bill for establishing two additional Deputy Postmasters General, now before Congress would pass— I thought not— He said others thought so too— And he told me of his visit to General Jackson, and of his taking tea with him; and other particulars equally interesting; and also of the settlement of some Estate at Leesburg, in which he has a concern— He is one of the Samples of a candid Office-hunter, and would have been more communicative, if I had manifested proportionable curiosity— He left me at the end of the Avenue.
I rode on horseback an hour before dinner, but my horse was so skittish that I was in constant danger of being thrown; and that would have cost me at least a broken limb— There is no other exercise half so good for my health; but of eight horses that I have mounted within these two years, not one has been safe. I was this day very well fatigued; the consequence of which was that the Evening was nearly lost both for reading and writing— I am still endeavouring to make out something from the Koran, all the good parts of which seem to me like the ravings of a religious Maniac; crazed by overstrained study of the Bible— The sublime ideas of the Godhead, are borrowed from the old Testament, but greatly impaired— The day of Judgment and future Retribution from the gospels; but the punishments of the next life are rendered ludicrous by the manner of announcing them; and the rewards are corrupting by their gross sensuality— One of the remarkable features of the New-Testament is the extreme purity of thought, enjoined by Christ, and observed in all the writings of the Apostles, in every thing relating to the female sex— The reverse is one of the disgusting features of the Koran.
9. IV. Good Friday.

Dr Condict, a member of the House of Representatives from New-Jersey introduced a friend of his from that State by the name of Thomas. Jonathan Elliott is publishing a collection of Debates in the State Conventions upon the Constitution of the United States; and he now proposes to publish a supplementary Volume containing a view or history of practical constructions of the Constitution by Congress. He came to-day, ostensibly to enquire of me where he could find Reports of the Debates in Congress from 1790 to 1795. I referred him to the Gazette of the United States; Andrew Brown’s Federal Gazette, and the Aurora Newspapers, and mentioned to him the principal topics of discussion which were agitated during that period— I also mentioned to him the fifth Volume of Marshall’s Life of Washington, and to Pitkin’s History of the United States for more particular information on those points, and lent him the fifth Volume of Marshall, that he might look over it more at leisure. He proposes to include in his collection the republication of the Journal of the Federal Convention of 1787.— The minutes of Judge Yates of New-York, who seceded from the Convention; and the pamphlet of Luther Martin— And I recommended to him also to look up the newspaper lucubrations of Mr Edmund Randolph on both sides of the Question—he having changed sides at least four times in the course of the formation and adoption of the Constitution. Elliott said he had written to Mr Madison, requesting his book for publication; but he had answered that he had particular reasons for declining the publication at present— Mr Elliott appeared to be satisfied with the information that I have him on the subject of his enquiries, and made some remarks indicating though not avowing a disposition to commence the publication of another Newspaper at this place.
He said the members of the present Administration were all personally unpopular here; but that there was no spirited newspaper to express the sentiments of the People— The Intelligencer and the Journal were both altogether inefficient, and a paper of very different character would be required. I gave no countenance to those overtures if they were intended as such; and no encouragement to continue the conversation in that channel— He told me that Meehan had been the nominal purchaser of the Washington City Gazette in 1825. but that John H. Eaton had written a Letter to him making himself responsible and that John P. Van Ness endorsed the Notes— But that the paper had been purchased by a subscription to which several persons had contributed, and he had been obliged to sue the Notes. I heard him without pressing any enquiries upon him; and doubt whether he would incline to tell the whole truth relating to this Transaction— I received from Joseph Blunt a Letter, and three half-sheets of Letter-press, being the last of my chapters upon Russia, Turkey and Greece for the American Annual Register— I revised them and answered Blunt’s Letter— There are three ridiculous errors of the Press on the last page, which I asked to have corrected—
10. IV. Saturday.

Returned from my daily walk before the Sun rose. The rain began soon after and continued the whole day— The Sale of Baron Krudener’s furniture was at last made. Since finishing the six chapters for the American Annual Register I am wasting time again; chiefly in miscellaneous reading. The 11th. Book of the familiar Epistles chiefly consists of the correspondence between Cicero and Decimus Brutus during the period of the last struggle with Antony. The alternation of hopes and fears, the exultation of victory and the anguish of disappointment; the agonies of expiring Liberty, are exhibited in this Book, with a power upon the imagination and heart which I cannot describe— The first Letter is from Decimus Brutus to Marcus Brutus and Cassius—written soon after the death of Caesar; when Antony was intending to use the veterans and the rabble to destroy the conspirators against Caesar— The second and third Letters are from Marcus Brutus and Cassius, who were Praetors, to Antony, the former demanding pledges of Antony, as Consul, for their safety in the City; the latter a spirited reply to an insolent answer from him, which is not given— There are then 23. Letters between Cicero and Decimus Brutus, designated Consul, and Imperator in Cisalpine Gaul. Then a Letter from Cicero to Matius with his answer, and finally one to Appius written at the time when Cicero was proposing to go into Greece— In the correspondence with Decimus Brutus, Cicero gently reproaches him with losing the opportunity of instantly pursuing and crushing Antony after his defeat— Brutus replies and shews that it was perhaps impossible. A fatality deemed to follow every attempt to save the Republic— The Death of both the Consuls, Hirtius and Pansa, one killed, the other mortally wounded at the battle of Mutina, was so portentous an Event that it was attributed to treachery— Tacitus intimates that Augustus was accused of having Pansa despatched by poison in dressing his wounds: and Velleius Paterculus says that
after the troops of Lepidus and Plancus went over to Antony, Decimus Brutus was gradually deserted by his own army; finally fled for refuge to the house of a noble friend of his named Camelus, and was there murdered by Ruffians employed by Antony, for the purpose— There is much excellent writing in the Correspondence with Brutus, the Laconism of whose style is more than once noticed by Cicero who tells him he will imitate it— One of his examples is “Quam multa, quam paucis!” The Letters are all short— In the 20th. Letter Brutus warns Cicero that Labeo Segulius, a man just like himself sibi simillimus, had told him that he had been with Octavius Caesar, and had much conversation with him about Cicero— That Octavius made no complaint against Cicero, except that Cicero had said—[“]laudandum, adolescentem, ornandum, tollandum.” and that Octavius added he would take care not to expose himself “ut tolli possit.” Decimus says that he believes Octavius said no such thing; but that Labeo said it to him, or fabricated the whole story—and Labeo further said the Veterans were extremely violent in their discourse and threats against Cicero—and were highly indignant that neither Octavius nor Decimus were of the Decemvirs; but that Cicero engrossed the whole distribution of favours to himself— Cicero answers with a bitter execration of the Tale-bearer Labeo—wonders that either Octavius or Decimus should suffer him to talk with them alone—and that he had told the same story to every one who would hear him— He does not deny having used the words; but says that he regrets very much that he is himself one of the Decemvirs; and that he had warmly urged that every one of the commanding Generals should be; but had been defeated by the same persons who opposed every thing— This incident perhaps accounts for the cold blooded treachery with which Octavius consented to the proscription of Cicero.
11. V:30. Sunday. Easter.

Heard Mr Upham of Salem, Morning and Evening—first from 2. Timothy 2.19. “Let every one that nameth the name of Christ, depart from iniquity.” The doctrine of which discourse was that the test of Christianity is good works— This doctrine I hold for sound, at least in the form in which it is announced by the text, as preceptive to the believer. Christianity is a system of Morals, and to depart from iniquity is the first of its duties. This indeed strictly considered is only negative and partial virtue— It is to abstain from wrong—and has bearing only upon our relations with others— The duty of the Christian is more comprehensive— It calls for active virtue—for self denial—for beneficence—for piety—for faith—all this will easily follow, with him who departs from iniquity. Mr Upham’s Sermon rather considered departure from iniquity as including all positive virtue, and without direct allusion to the calvinistic creed of Salvation by faith, and the atonement, reasoned against it by presenting the departure from iniquity as the whole sum of Christianity. The Evening Sermon was from 2. Corinthians 6.2. “Behold, now is the accepted time,” and it presented with great power of argument and persuasion, a truth which no one can question; which all acknowledge; but which few turn to practical account— The Sentiment in the text was addressed specially to the Corinthians, urging them to separate themselves from unbelievers, and not to receive the Grace of God in vain— But Mr Upham’s commentary gave it a general application, of reference to the discharge of all social duties. It was
against procrastination; and Horace’s Carpe diem, would have been a theme as well adapted to the Discourse, as the text itself— The argument was well pressed home, and perhaps not one of the auditory felt more deeply than myself its force, its truth, its importance— Would that it could have its full effect upon my conduct! Mr Upham did not very empathetically dwell upon the infinite consequence of his doctrine with reference to Salvation or preparation for death; but he left each of his hearers to make this application for himself— He said truly that whoever would accurately observe the character and conduct of his personal acquaintance, would invariably find that their usefulness and success in the world depended almost entirely upon the relative practical effect which they gave to this axiom—now is the excepted time— He said that now, was in truth all that Man could call Time— The past was gone—it was part of Eternity— The future was beyond the controul of Man—to multitudes it never came now was therefore the only moment of his existence of which man would dispose— And as a vivid illustration of the utter importance of man, to controul the future, he adverted to the phenomenon of the circulation of the blood— That perpetual miracle, the suspension of which for a single instant puts an end to human life— May I hope that this Lesson may be of some service to me, even for a few days? I heard it by accident, finding that there was no evening service at Mr Campbell’s.
12. IV. Monday.

A dull and gloomy day—doubly so to me from the memory of what it once was. I am conscious of the duty, to rejoice with gratitude for all the blessings yet dispensed by a kind Providence; instead of repining at the loss of those withdrawn. If I cannot choose but feel, let me at least forbear to complain— Early in the Evening Mr Foot and Judge Burnet, Senators of the United States, called and mentioned to us that the nomination of Isaac Hill, second Comptroller of the Treasury, was this day rejected by the Senate—33 to 15 every Senator being present. Hill was the Editor of the New-Hampshire Patriot, one of the most slanderous Newspapers against the late Administration, and particularly against me, in the whole Country. But he published and circulated besides a pamphlet, containing a false and infamous imputation not only upon me, but upon my wife— The author of this pamphlet and imputation was Jonathan Russell; but these gentlemen said it was this day urged, and did actually occasion the rejection of Hill’s nomination. They said that six or eight of the 15 who voted for the confirmation said that if the vote should be postponed till to-morrow Morning, unless a satisfactory explanation should be given of the fact, they would vote against the nomination also— Two other nominations of libellers quite as profligate as Hill, were this day confirmed— Mr Silsbee called and introduced Mr Mosely and Mr Upham, who is to preach here three Sundays more. They were all in great concern at a murder perpetrated last Monday night at Salem, upon Joseph White a wealthy man is his eighty second year—found dead in his bed, with a mortal blow on his temple—and ten deadly stabs in the body— No theft or robbery of the house; and no discovery or promising trace of the murderer— They had also news of the annual Election in Massachusetts— Governor Lincoln is re-elected by a large majority, but with considerable opposition. In Boston there is a concentration of the Spirit of party, stronger
than for several preceding years— The Suffolk Senators are elected by three fourths of the votes— Alexander H Everett at the head of the list— I wrote a short Letter to Mr Curtis and Mrs Boylston— The 12th. Book of the familiar Epistles contains 13 Letters of Correspondence with Caius Cassius all after the death of Caesar. Two from Publius Lentulus, one to Cicero, and one to the Senate and People— One from Trebonius, shortly before his death, to Cicero—and 14 to Quintus Cornificius, prefect in Africa, and afterwards in Syria under Caesar; but 9 of them were written after the death of Caesar— This Cornificius is supposed to be the author of the Rhetorics to Herennius— Cicero sends him with Letter 17. his preface de optimo genere dicendi, and delicately hints that there was a difference of opinion between them on the theory of Oratory. The Letters in this book, like those of the 17th. are invaluable. But I have scored so many passages in them, that I have neither time nor room to remark upon them here. I can not pass however the remark in the 18th. Letter, where after telling Cornificius that if he were at Rome, he would see many things which would not delight him—things which delight not Caesar himself, he adds. Such is ever the issue of civil Wars—things are done, not only at the will of the victor, but also in compliance to those by whose aid the victory was achieved— In the 25th. Letter he charges Antony with drunkenness in the Senate—
13. V. Tuesday.

I have been persuaded to alter my time of taking my daily exercise; from the morning before breakfast to the middle of the day. One motive for which is the wish to shake off if possible the catarrhal cough, which has hung upon me nearly these four Months— Mr Whittlesey, Member of the House of Representatives from Ohio, introduced two young men; one of whom named Allen was the Son of a member of the House from Connecticut in 1798 and 1799— I called as I had some time since promised at the chamber of John Cranch, where I met his brother Edward. He had no Canvas ready, and asked me to call again to-morrow. T. B. Johnson dined with us and spent the Evening here— I began a Letter to A. H. Everett, and it led me to three Articles written by him, in as many recent numbers of the North-American Review— The last upon the Tariff—one upon Malthus’s Definitions in Political Economy, and one upon professor Cousin’s new System of Philosopy, which is mystifying the French Nation. I fell yesterday upon his Review in 1825 of Lord Byron’s Works; which contains much sound criticism; with an estimate perhaps on the whole too severe of his Poetry— A century and a half ago, Madame de Sevigné predicted that the taste for Racine, and for Coffee, would soon pass away; and surely she did not imagine that her own fondling Letters to her daughter would be read after a hundred and fifty years, to prove how weak her own judgment was in matters of taste— It is vain presumption for mortals to foretell what taste will be lasting, and what is destined to perish— Byron has been extolled, as the sublimest of Poets— There are passages in all his Poems, which I have thought charming—but mixed with so much that was disgusting, that I never believed his popularity would be lasting— His versification is so destitute of sustained harmony—many of his thoughts are so strained; his sentiments so unamiable, his misanthropy so gloomy, his images so grossly indelicate, his libertinism so shameless, his merriment such grinning of a ghastly smile; that I have always believed his verses would soon rank with forgotten
things. But Byron was one of those writers whose lives are interwoven in all their works— The author keeps his reader forever in sight of himself— Such writers must always be vicious and miserable— For the world will suffer no man to entertain them long with his good deeds, or his happiness—

lg.l: It is a witness still of excellence
To put a strange face on its own perfection.

div.p: but the bad son—the faithless husband—the unfeeling father, by keeping the world in mind of their vices, seem to command sympathy by the mere faculty of painting their own wretchedness— The last Scenes of his life gave him a new and even a virtuous claim to commiseration; and his associates who survived him, have kept his memory alive; by making books to sell, out of the loose adventures, and characteristic anecdotes of his life— Moore is now making the final, and largest speculation of this kind; and it may somewhat lengthen out his immortality. I shall not hazard a prophecy against him.— Morning visit from Count de Menou who is out of health
14. V. Wednesday.

Captain Newell called this morning to enquire concerning the purchase of a horse for which I referred him to my Son John. I sat an hour to John Cranch, and then walked round the Capitol Square. Met Mr John Connell who called upon me in the Evening. He told me that the Secretary of State, Mr Van Buren, had sent for him to see him upon the subject of the claims of our citizens upon France, for which he has some new Negotiation on foot— He says that Mr Van-Buren wrote last Summer a circular to the claimant, in the principal Cities inviting them to appoint committees from each place to come here, and confer with him; which most if not all of them had declined— Mrs Adams dined this day with her brother— A Mr William H. Hadley brought a subscription book, for building a second Baptist Church in this City— They have purchased Land at the Corner of the Post-Office Square. Dr Semple is preaching for them now; but in the course of a few Months is to return to Virginia. I wrote to A. H. Everett. The 13th. Book of Cicero’s familiar Epistles consists of 79 Letters: to a great variety of persons—all short; and almost all Letters of recommendation. The first three are to Caius Memmius, then in exile at Athens— This is the man who had seduced the wives of Lucullus and of Pompey—and who made and proclaimed the infamous bargain exposed in the Letter to Atticus 4.18. Among the Letters of recommendation the 10th. is introductory of Marcus Terentius Varro, going as Quaestor into Cisalpine Gaul, to Marcus Brutus, commanding there by appointment from Caesar— After highly commending Varro, he says—I make no promises for him of qualities, concerning which you yourself will judge— But yet in all new connections, the first access, and the commendation by which the doors of Friendship are opened is important, and this is what I wished to do in this Letter: the same thing must be effected by the necessary duties of the quaestor’s Office— It will however suffer no diminution, by this addition— The 15th. is a very remarkable recommendation of a young man named Praecilius to Julius Caesar, when Consul for the fourth time, without Colleague— It is written under great and aukward embarrassment: with
five successive quotations of verses from Homer and Euripides— He alludes to his own opposition to Caesar in the Civil Wars; for which he says the father of Praecilius had always reproached and derided him— It is apologetical—written in an assumed tone of pleasantry; and concludes by observing that he had used a new style of Letter-writing to shew him that he intended no vulgar recommendation— There is more uniformity and less of interest in the other Letters of this book than in any of the others—
15. V. Thursday.

As I was walking out, I met Mr Sparks who was coming to see me; and walked with him round the Capitol Hill— He said he had just returned from a visit to Pittsburg, where he had been to inspect the spot of Braddock’s defeat in 1755. which he had done much to his satisfaction— There was no person left there, who had any recollection of the Event, but there were many traditions, from which he had collected valuable information. I asked him when he expected to publish his Correspondence of Washington— He thought there would be a Volume out before the end of this year— I asked him how many volumes he supposed would complete the work—he said ten or twelve— I observed that the English Quarterly Review advised him to retrench the publication, and give but little—advice quite natural for Englishmen, who the less they heard about Washington, and the American Revolution the better pleased they were. He said that he had difficulties with the proprietors of the papers— That he could never obtain them from the late Judge Washington, till he held out to him the prospect of money, to be made by the publication, and his wish was to make the most money from it that he could— The present proprietor, Coll. Washington, now a member of Congress had the same disposition— It was probable that a collection of four Volumes, would raise more money than ten or twelve, but he thought that the publication of all those, which would be useful as historical documents would be better for the public. Mr Sparks made some enquiries about Thomas Johnson, who he said appeared from Washington’s papers to have been one of his intimate and confidential friends and asked if I knew who was in possession of Mr Johnson’s papers— I gave him an account of Mr Johnson and his family, and said I supposed his papers were in possession of Mr Graham of Frederick—but it was not probable they would be of much importance. He said he would write to Mr Graham— We conversed upon other subjects relating to the American Revolution— Upon Hutchinson’s History— Lord Mansfield, Burke, and the author of Junius. He spoke also of Graham’s History of the American Colonies; which he said had not succeeded in England— This is very natural; but is the very reason why it ought to succeed here— Mrs Adams and Mary spent the Evening at Mr Frye’s. Mr Bailey and Mr Connell with me— Connell’s goes to-morrow Morning—returning to Philadelphia— Bailey spoke of the party movements here— A Party public dinner was got up on Tuesday, professedly in honour of Jefferson’s birth day— Announced pompously in the Newspapers—with the names of 3 Committees of Members of Congress—a Committee of Arrangements—a Committee of invitations, and a Committee of Toasts— The Account of it has not yet been published; but Bailey says several of the Pennsylvania members withdrew, on discovering that the Toasts were anti-Tariff. Yesterday the Buffalo and New-Orleans road bill was rejected at the third reading, upon which Philip P. Barbour, moved to adjourn; saying that the House had done enough for one day of glory. Some of the Tariff men took this in dudgeon, and
this day the vote of rejection was reconsidered, and the Bill was laid on the Table to be taken up again at the next Session. An attempt was also made in the Senate on Tuesday, to reconsider the vote rejecting the nomination of Isaac Hill as second Comptroller, but could not be carried; an so at the dinner Hill being present was toasted, with an insult upon the Senate— Mr Bailey mentioned to me that it was his intention to decline a re-election to the next Congress, and expressed a wish to go into the Senate of the State.
16. V. Friday.

Sat to J. Cranch, who upon my asking him if the Portrait was finished requested one short sitting more, which I promised him on Monday or Tuesday— My occupation now again consists almost wholly of reading; and in the North American Review I have read the Article by Alexander H. Everett on the Politics of Europe, and that of Jared Sparks on the Early Diplomatic History of the United States— That of Everett is written with his Talent, and general knowledge of European Affairs— It is almost entirely upon the recent War between Russia and Turkey— He considers it altogether in a political point of view, and with reference to its probable effect on the balance of Power in Europe— His opinions with regard to the bearing of this subject on the policy of the United States are sound, but of the religious interests involved in it, there is not the slightest notice— All the European speculations that I have seen on this topic are equally silent, on that which I regard as a consideration for transcending all the others. To me it appears that the dissolution of the Turkish Empire must necessarily be followed by the extinction of the Mahometan Imposture— My design has been broadly to present that idea and hope, to the Christian World—but if noticed at all, it will be deemed extravagant and fanatical— Mr Sparks’s Article is upon the Life of Arthur Lee; written in the Spirit that I had expected, but without much power. The fourteenth Book of the Epistles at diversos, consisting of 24 Letters is exclusively familiar, that is of family Letters, addressed, chiefly to his wife Terentia; but some of them to her and their Son and daughter; and some jointly with his Son to his wife and daughter. The four first of the Letters were written while he was in exile, and are too querulous. Others before and others after the battle of Pharsalia— Most of them very short, and all affectionate. He was afterwards divorced from Terentia, Plutarch says he was reproached for this by Antony in his answer to the Philippics— That he soon after the divorce married a young girl, whose Guardian he was; for her Fortune—and then put her away because she was not sufficiently afflicted at the Death of his daughter Tullia. There is only one Letter in which he alludes to his second marriage, after his divorce from Terentia— The 14th. of the 4th. Book— In answer to congratulations from Cneius Plancius—he says— As to your good wishes upon what I have done, I am very sure that they are sincere; but in such a wretched a time, I should have sought no new condition of life, had I not, upon my return, found my domestic affairs in no better state than those of the Republic—but when by the baseness of those to whom in return for immortal benefits received from me, my welfare and fortunes ought to have been above all things dear, I found within my own walls, nothing safe, nothing but snares, I thought it indispensable to fortify myself by the faithfulness of new connections, against the perfidy of the old— This is a melancholy picture—how many heart-aches it reveals!
17. V. Saturday.

Resumed my morning walk before breakfast, which is more cheering and pleasant than at any other time of the day, and with less consumption of that invaluable article, Time. Mr Stone the engraver introduced his brother in Law, a young man named Lenthall, who has engaged in the ship-yard under Mr Humphreys, receiving instruction in Naval Architecture. But our government proposes retrenchment in the expenses of Ship-yards, and Mr Lenthall finds it necessary to go, and seek his fortunes else where. He has been offered a passage in the ship, purchased at Philadelphia for the Emperor of Russia, and wishes to obtain employment, in the Russian Ship-yards; or if not there, in France or England. Mr Stone asked Letters of Recommendation from me for him; but I knew no person, to whom I could address them. Mr Pope came to take leave; being on the point of departure for his Government of Arkansas— Mrs Adams saw him; Not withstanding his eminent services to the present Administration, he has not been able to obtain a more distinguished appointment by his attendance of upwards of two months here. We have had very little intercourse with him; though probably quite as much as he desired. Mr Johnson was here, and Mrs Silsbee with her two daughters— The Evening was very warm, and I took a short walk at dusk. The Winter Evenings are past, and the lassitude of Spring is coming on; so that I find it already scarcely practicable either to read or write after dinner— My Son John gave me some account of the business that he has been doing at the Columbia Mills the last year—a neat profit of about two hundred dollars is the result of his constant, indefatigable attention, of Mills which cost me 30,000 dollars, and a capital of 3500 dollars that I have furnished him. Yet there is no other mode of occupation, by which his prospects would be fairer— We must proceed, and trust that there may yet be a blessing in reserve. I wrote in answer to a Letter from Joseph Blunt, and about half a page of the Dissertation upon Parties in the United States which I began last Spring and which yet remains unfinished—
18. V. Sunday.

Heard at the Unitarian Church Mr Upham, in the morning from Romans 1:16. [“]For I am not ashamed of the gospel of Christ: for it is the power of God, unto salvation to every one that believeth:”—and after observing that these words were saint Paul’s, and explaining the reasons which gave propriety to the expression of them; the discourse made an application of them to the present times; recommending that every individual to examine himself, to ascertain whether he is not ashamed of the Gospel of Christ— The influences which might occasion the sentiment, in the days of St. Paul, it was observed, were different from those which might produce the same effect now— Then, the humble condition, and apparently lowly birth of Jesus, the persecutions he endured, his seemingly ignominious death—the subsequent dispersion of his followers; their obscurity, their sufferings, the powers of the world exercised against them had all a tendency to make even the disciples of Jesus, ashamed of his Gospel—and although these causes no longer exist, there are others which operate with equal force upon Christians of the present time— There
were three tests by which a Christian might prove himself at this day not ashamed of the Gospel of Christ— 1 by his Life. 2 by his influence— 3. by his personal devotion to the cause— In the evening, after ascertaining that there was no service at Mr Campbell’s I heard again Mr Upham, from 1. Corinthians 2.9. “Eye hath not seen, nor ear heard, neither have entered into the heart of man, the things which God hath prepared for them that love him”— In the Sermon it was observed that these words have no intimation of the nature of the enjoyments of a future State—the promise had reference only to the degree— In all ages, and in every Nation, among whom future retribution was an Article of Faith or hope, the pictures of happiness to be enjoyed, were of the most exquisite kind. There was an accumulation of all that constituted the most exquisite enjoyment upon Earth— Of all the senses the sight was that which ministered most to human enjoyment—and there was much eloquent description of the pleasures naturally derived from what the eye hath seen— A similar analysis was made of the enjoyments of hearing—and then it was remarked, how prolific the imagination of man had been in painting to itself the felicitations of the future Elysium—and then returning to the text we were encouraged to the certain hope that the real enjoyments of Heaven will transcend all this. The fascination of the discourse, which was listened to with the deepest attention, consisted in the multitude of details— It was a continual climax furnished by the text itself; and the conclusion naturally drawn from it was that this promise of transcendent bliss in a future life, was the most efficacious motive to embrace Christianity— There was an argument suggested though not much pressed, against the gloomy doctrines of those who address themselves only to the fears of men: with a remembrance that the first proclamation of the gospel; was as of glad tidings of great joy! I was much entertained and edified by this discourse— Mr Upham’s elocution is good notwithstanding a slight impediment in his speech, by the occasional inability of giving its true sound to the l.— John dined at Mr Frye’s— Mrs Adams and Mary spent the Evening with Mr Pope, at Mr Johnson’s— Mr D. Brent was here
19. V. Monday.

Mr Ruggles, Senator from Ohio, introduced three of his friends. Mr Yarnall had been here before. Mr Lincoln of Boston came with Mr Sharp, a Baptist Clergyman, and Mr Williams of Florida accompanied Mr White the Territorial delegate— Both houses of Congress adjourned this day, to attend the funeral of Alexander Smyth, one of the members of the House from Virginia— He died the day before yesterday, after a short illness. I took a short walk about midday, and another at the dusk of Evening. The 15th. book of the Epistles ad diversos contains 21. Letters. The first and second are public despatches from the Government of Cilicia, addressed to the Consuls, Praetors, Tribunes of the People and Senate, and contain the narrative of his military operations against the Parthians. They are succeeded by
two Letters to Marcus Cato, the latter relating much more in detail his warlike atchievements, and intreating Cato most earnestly to favour in the Senate his claim for a decree of Supplications, equivalent to a modern Te Deum. This was one of the usual accompaniments, or preliminaries to a Triumph— Cato did not comply with this request; but the Senate did decree the Supplications— Cato in his answer says that he is glad the Senate did pass the decree though he could not vote for its adoption— His reason for which, he tells him is, that he ascribes to Cicero himself all the glory of his great actions; while the Supplications would give a great part of the credit to the Gods— There is more of complaisance than of ingenuousness in this apology, which in our time would scarcely be deemed consistent with sentiments of true piety— Cicero replies by thanking him for his good opinion, and for his rejoicing at that which he could approve— Adding that he proposes to demand the honours of a Triumph—on which occasion he again prays Cato to favour him, or at least to rejoice again if he should succeed— The breaking out of the Civil War immediately after his return from Cilicia prevented him from obtaining the Triumph— The Letters to Cato are followed by several to Marcus and Caius Marcellus, then by two to Lucius Paulus, acting and designated Consul’s; then by six to Caius Cassius, and finally two to Trebonius— There is a Letter to Trebonius in the 10th. book, and several to Cassius in the 12th. The separation from each other of Letters to the same person shews the careless arrangement of them; and the Chronological order is much disregarded— Cassius was an Epicurian, and Cicero occasionally rallies him upon his philosophy. In the 18th. Letter, written in the midst of Caesar’s Spanish War he says after apologizing for the shortness of his Letter— [“]It would be longer if I had any gossiping news, for to touch upon any thing serious would be dangerous— You will say, we can laugh— Faith not easily—but we have no other consolation— Where then say you is Philosophy?— Your’s is in the kitchen— Mine is troublesome; for I am ashamed of servitude. So to avoid hearing the rebuke of Plato, I task myself to something else.”— I have no better lesson but Christian resignation.
20. IV:15. Tuesday.

Between three and four this morning I was awakened by a distant Serenade, and finding no prospect of further sleep, arose soon after four and trudged my walk round the Capitol Square, returning near home I met judge Spencer— The Chevalier Torlade d’Azambuja the Minister of the king of Portugal de facto Don Miguel, called upon me, and shewed me a Letter that he had written to Mr Clay, making enquiries concerning the official standing of Mr Barroso Pereira— Tis a very complicated case of diplomacy. Mr Barroso first appeared here as a Consul of the old and now deceased king of Portugal; after his return to Europe from Brazil; and under the Constitutional Government. Then came the partition between him and his eldest Son the present Emperor of Brazil; and his own assumption of the title of Emperor— Upon some notification of this by Mr Barrozo, being at that time Secretary of State, I answered his Note, without giving the king the title of Emperor, but naming him according to the old diplomatic style, His most faithful Majesty. This did not satisfy Mr Barroso who returned my Note declining to receive it unless with a formal acknowledgment of the Imperial title of his Master— No further notice was taken of him until some Months afterwards the old king died, and settled all questions respecting his title— At his death he left one of his daughters Regent, till his Son
the Emperor of Brazil should take the Government into his hands. Don Miguel was then an Exile at Vienna— Mr Barroso exercised his functions as Consul during the Regency, and until Miguel assumed the Crown.— On this last Event, Mr Barroso wrote a formal Note to the Secretary of State declaring that he was no longer the Representative of the Portuguese government, and pronouncing Don Miguel an Usurper. This was in July 1828— Mr Clay acknowledged the receipt of his Note, and informed him it would remain of Record in the Department. A Month afterwards Mr Torlade arrived with credentials, from the Portuguese Regency, but claiming to be received as accredited by Miguel as King of Portugal— Without entering into the question of Don Miguel’s legitimacy, I declined receiving Mr Torlade, on the principle that as by his own shewing, the authority by which he had been accredited was extinct, he could not be received upon those credentials—and the Government of the United States could not decide in advance upon any other credentials which he might afterwards receive— And thus the matter rested at the close of the last Administration— Mr Torlade received his new Credentials a few days before that time—but I left to my Successor the decision of the question whether Don Miguel should be recognized as king of Portugal, or not: as the responsibility of the recognition must necessarily fall upon the present Administration, and Miguel was then acknowledged by no other European Government. Mr Torlade was soon after received; and has ever since been ineffectually claiming from Mr Barroso the Archives of the Portuguese Legation. He first applied to the Secretary of State for compulsive means in aid of his demand. The opinion of the Attorney-General was taken, and he was refered to the judicial tribunals— The Court in Pennsylvania decided that Mr Barroso having once been received as a diplomatic Agent, was entitled to the privileges of the Laws of Nations, and not amenable to compulsive process here— The question is to be brought before the Supreme Court of the United States, and Mr Torlade hinted that he might have occasion for my testimony before the Court— His object now was only to write to Mr Clay, to make some enquiries of him respecting Mr Barroso’s self-divestment of the diplomatic character in July 1828. He said he proposed to send this Letter to the Secretary of State, with a request that it may be transmitted to Mr Clay; but he had thought as it related to transactions under my administration, that he ought before sending it to communicate it to me. I told him I saw no objection to his sending it as he proposed, and had no doubt he would receive from Mr Clay a candid answer—
21. IV.30. Wednesday.

Mr Whittlesey introduced a Mr Fitch from the State of Ohio. He had also an account rendered by three Commissioners appointed by me in March 1825 to mark and lay out a road from St. Louis Missouri to the border of the Republic of Mexico— There was an appropriation of thirty thousand dollars for this work— The Account of the Commissioners exceeds that sum by about 1500 dollars, and the Secretary of War now calls for an additional appropriation. Mr Whittlesey enquired if I had any recollection of the appointment of those Commissioners or if I had any knowledge of this account— I had no knowledge of the account though it is dated in November 1827: but I had a general recollection of the appointment and proceedings of the Commissioners. Mr Whittlesey
said he applied to me, because the Secretary of War refused to give any information to individual Senators or Members of the House, and even to Committees, yielding it only to formal Resolutions of either house— Jonathan Elliott called on me again, concerning the third Volume which he is about to publish, on the federal Constitution— He had a list of heads—embracing questions of Constitutional Construction, and of opinions of many persons upon them; and asked me if I could give him any additional suggestion connected with the subject— I mentioned to him several persons who had delivered opinions upon questions of Constitutional Construction, and recommended to him to add to his list of heads, the acquisition of Louisiana, as the most important of them all; which he said he would. Coll. Barnard, who was the member of the last Congress from Rochester in the State of New-York was here—travelling at present for his health— Mr Fendall called, to enquire if I had finished the Dissertation upon parties in the United Sates which I had commenced last Spring— I had not; but recommended to him to begin upon his work without waiting for it— We had a long conversation upon the aspect of political affairs at the present time, and the movements of the present Administration— The nominations are yet labouring in the Senate, and he says that there is a Report of a Committee of the Senate, bearing so heavily upon J. H. Eaton in his connection with Timberlake that Lewis the Chief Clerk of the War Department, and Smith the Register of the Treasury, are both gone to New-York, to seek counteracting evidence. There has been another great agitation at the President’s house— The Jefferson dinner was a trick of Calhoun’s against Van-Buren, as the Harrisburg and Albany nominations of Jackson for re-election were a trick of Van-Buren’s against Calhoun— Mrs Frye with her Son Tom dined with us: and after dinner, I rode with my Son John, the long round in his Gig. With my company and the Universal Songster I lost my day.
22. V. Thursday.

Rising at the dawn of day, I walk to avoid the necessity of reading or writing by Candlelight of the morning— The approach of Summer already makes it almost impossible in the Evening. Mr Hodgson came to inform me that the act of Congress by which a small Clerkship with a Salary of 1000 dollars a year is added to the Department of State, and to which he has the promise of being appointed received yesterday the Signature of the President— This is something—but Hodgson would render more essential Service to the Country in Greece, or at Constantinople— He said he believed that a Mr Rind, of New-York, who has been appointed Consul of the United States at Odessa, and who embarked for his Post last November, had instructions to make some stay at Constantinople; and that Commodore Biddle had also Instructions upon the subject— I asked Mr Hodgson if among the Manuscripts he has brought home there was a copy of the Koran; and of the Sonna— He said there was of the Koran—and he believed of the Sonna— The sixteenth Book of Epistles ad Diversos, consists of 27. Letters, all addressed to Tiro the freedman of Cicero; written some by him—some by his Son— Some by his brother Quintus, and some by two, or all of them— The Letters of Cicero, are in a Style different from those in the other books— They are full of kindness and affection, mingled with a spice of authority marking the relations between the parties— It appears from them, that Cicero, on his return from his Proconsular Government of Cilicia, was obliged to leave Tiro behind him at Patrae, he having fallen sick of a fever, so that he could not proceed— He was detained there a considerable time; for there are several Letters in which Cicero specially enjoins upon him, not to
come on until so surely convalescent as to incur no danger of a relapse—and he gives him credits to pay the physician handsomely— In one Letter he says— Your good offices to me are numberless—at home—in the forum—in the City—in the Province— In private—in public—in my studies—in my literary pursuits. You will surpass them all, if I can see you, and I hope, in health. All the rest are in the same tone— Only two or three of them mention politics and those barely in general terms— The Letters from the Son affect pleasantry—the last two are from Quintus— in the 26th. he jokingly reproves Tiro, for having neglected an opportunity of writing to him— You must engage Marcus, says he, to prove by a deeply studied, and much commented Oration, that you have not been to blame. And I must plainly insist that you should do, as I remember my mother used to do, of old. She sealed up empty bottles, so that others might not be found empty, by surprize: so you, if you have nothing to write; must still write to shew it is not by a furtive omission— In the last Letter he inveighs indignantly against both the Consuls Hirtius and Pansa. Both of them soon after lost their lives in the cause of the Country, although the Sincerity of their attachment to it is very doubtful— I rode with John this after dinner to the Mill.
23. IV. Friday.— Fahrenheit 80.

Walk before day-light. Weather at Summer heat— Mr Brent brought me the book and pamphlets that I had requested—and he shewed me a Note from the French Chargé d’Affaires, Count Menou, complaining that a discriminating duty had been expected of 10 per Cent on the Cargo of a French vessel entered at Pensacola, in contravention as he represents to the Convention of 28. June 1822 between the United States and France— By the Florida-cession Treaty it was stipulated that for twelve years to commence three Months after the exchange of the Ratification, the vessels of Spain and their Cargoes, should pay no other or higher duties in the Ports of the Province than those of the United States; and that during that time these privileges should be enjoyed by no other Nation. This privilege commenced in June 1821. and will continue till June 1833. By the first and second Articles of the Convention with France; a scale of discriminating duties upon Cargoes, not to be exceeded is prescribed; and by the 5th. Article a discriminating duty of Tonnage is also fixed— The Convention itself was to continue for two years—and further, each party having after that time the power to put an end to it, by giving six Months notice to the other— And the discriminating duties of the first and second Articles were to be diminished, one fourth part every year—so that in June 1826 they ceased altogether. There is of course since June 1826 no discriminating duties upon the Cargoes of French Vessels—being of French produce, to be levied in the Ports of the United States— The Collector of Pensacola did however levy the ten per Cent additional duty on the Cargo of the French ship Pactole; upon which Count Menou claims the benefit of the Convention— The Collector of the Port in 1828 had written for instructions, to the Secretary of the Treasury, and upon reference of his Letter to the first Comptroller, Mr Anderson answered it, as if the question had been applicable only to the Tonnage—upon which the discriminating duty is unquestionably to be paid— But the Count de Menou’s claim of exemption is
only for the Cargo, and I told Mr Brent I thought it was valid—and not incompatible with the engagement to Spain in the Florida cession Treaty— French vessels being still subject to the discriminating duty on Tonnage, and therefore not entitled to the privileges of Vessels of the United States— I said it was however a question upon the construction of the Treaties, on which it would be well to take the opinion of the Attorney General; which he said he would do— Visit from Mr Rush, who has been twice absent—several weeks; in Pennsylvania; and who proposes to remove thither with his family: but has not yet determined to what part of the State he will go— I told him I thought he was right in the intention to remove; and hoped he would be instrumental in saving the Union—which I believed depended entirely upon Pennsylvania; and upon the accomplishment of a great change in her political partialities. This is the forlorn hope of the Union.— I took an hour’s ride with my Son John after dinner— Finished this morning the reading of Cicero’s Epistles.
24. Saturday. V.

The morning was the warmest that has been this Season; but with a change of wind at Night it was almost cold enough for Snow. Mr Naudain a Senator from Delaware came and introduced Mr Kinsey Johns Chief Justice of that State, and father of the Representative in Congress from the District— Took half an hour’s ride with John after dinner— The change of weather has made me sluggish in writing— I read this morning Cicero’s Oration for Roscius the Comedian—a fragment. There are three books of Epistles to Quintus, but there is no apparent reason why they should be so divided— The first of the first book was written when Quintus was Propraetor in the Province of Asia— He had according to the usage drawn this command by lot—had held it two years; and it was now continued to him for a third— It is a long Letter of advice; and full of admirable precepts to guard him against the common vices of the provincial Governors—many of whom plundered and oppressed without mercy or controul, the People of their Provinces— Cicero disclaims all intention of advising his brother against this, well knowing that it was not in his Nature to be guilty of such atrocious offences— But he warns him to avoid all partialities or favoritism in his relations with the inhabitants. To hold a severe controul over all his subordinate Officers— To suffer none of his Slaves or freedmen to exercise influence over him in any matter of business—and above all to rule his own Spirit, and refrain from Anger—to which he was not a little addicted. It is an admirable Letter—fit at this day to serve as a manual of morals to every man in authority, and even to every father of a family. The next Letter shews however that it was not altogether efficacious upon Quintus— It reproves him severely for the ascendancy which a freedman named Statius had acquired over him, and for certain rude and insulting expressions, which Quintus was charged with having used, as well in his conversations as in Letters— It is apparent that Quintus was a rash, hot-headed, and harsh tempered man— From other Letters, particularly to Atticus, it is clear that he lived upon very bad terms with his wife—and with his Son, who was much worse than himself— Quintus seems to have been an honest man, and a Patriot— Sincerely devoted to his brother, whose attachment to him, like all his domestic affections, was ardent and faithful— In the first book of the Letters to Quintus there are only 4 Letters—16 in the second, and 9 in the third— After the two Letters of advice, the rest are written
at various times, and upon private and public affairs, intermingled together. In the 11th. Letter of the 2d: book, he mentions the Poems of Lucretius, as abounding more in art than in Genius—and says [“]cum veneris, virum te putabo, si Sallustii Empedocleas legeris; hominem non putabo.” What was the Empedocles of Sallust and what was the difference between Vir and homo?— I suppose, the difference between virility and humanity— Plutarch says that both Quintus and his Son, were murdered by the Assassins of Mark Antony—
25. V. Sunday. Rain.

Heard at the Unitarian Church Mr Upham, in the morning from Matthew 11.15. [“]He that hath ears to hear, let him hear.” There is a very clear and strong connection between Mr Upham’s texts and his Sermons, though it is not always immediately perceived. In this case he considered the emphatic call of Jesus upon his disciples, to hear, as a distinct and forcible appeal to their Reason, to judge of his doctrines, by the dictates of their own understandings— The discourse was an argument urged with great earnestness and ingenuity in behalf of the exercise of the Reason upon the doctrines of Christianity— He contended that the doctrine which requires Faith, independent of the exercise of Reason, is precisely the same as the doctrine of the Infidel— It admits that Revelation can not be maintained by Reason— The Infidel affirms the same thing. He rejects Revelation, because he says it will not abide the test of Reason— The other resorts to Faith, precisely upon the same ground. He also pointed out the distinction between things above comprehension and things contrary to reason. Said it was impossible to believe that which the mind could not comprehend— Instance; the grass grows—the tide rises— These are facts perfectly comprehensible— The causes of these phenomena, reason cannot indeed comprehend—nor are they subjects of belief. This is a difficult and delicate topic— Perhaps we must believe some things which our reason cannot comprehend— The conclusions of human reason differ, in different individuals— There are many things upon which it can come to no conclusion— Belief must then be founded upon confidence; or upon authority; and must depend upon the Will— Mrs Adams went with me in the Evening— The text was from Matthew 7:13. “Enter ye in at the strait gate.”— This text seems to suggest doctrines rather of the Calvinistic than of the Unitarian denomination. He explained the text as importing in the original that the gate is narrow as well as strait, and the difficulties and obstructions in the way of life are so great and multiplied, that only few are successful in pursuing it— He then entered into the enquiry what were the causes of these difficulties and obstructions, which he found to be two—Erroneous opinions; and irresolution. Erroneous opinions were of two kinds— For example The belief in the tri personality of the Deity was a serious and very injurious error, because it confused our ideas of the Divine Nature, and obscured the simple and sublime idea of the Unity of God— But it was not a fatal error, because it had no unfavourable effect upon the moral conduct. But if the Creator, the Preserver, and the Governor of all worlds, should be taken; not in that endearing, and affectionate character of a father, in which we are commanded by our Lord to consider him, but as a cruel tyrant delighting in the wretchedness of his Creatures, this has so direct a tendency to deprave and corrupt the conduct of the believer that
we might safely pronounce it a fatal error— The second Cause of obstructions to the passage of the narrow gate was irresolution—want of firmness to do that which we know and feel to be right— Upon which he appealed to the consciousness of his hearers, and made some sensible but not novel remarks— Mr Upham has an uncommon faculty of rivetting the attention of his hearers. There was an Anthem sung at the close of each of the Services.
26. V. Monday— Rain—Clear

After heavy rain great part of the Night, and for an hour after I rose this morning it held up and I walked my round before Breakfast. It cleared up towards night and the Sun Set in a Chrystal Sky— Mr Bell, Senator from New Hampshire paid me a Morning visit. He mentioned that many of the nominations are yet pending in the Senate; and said it was generally rumoured that Isaac Hill would be renominated to the Senate for the Office of second Comptroller: and he thought in that event the nomination would pass by the casting vote of the Vice-President.
