Mr Bell says that the action of the Senate now depends upon Tazewell; who is discontented, and disapproves of almost every thing that is done; but votes for all that he disapproves— Tazewell as to the question of the succession to the Presidency is for Calhoun in preference to Van Buren— The Collection of Cicero’s Epistles concludes with a Book of 18 Letters to Brutus; followed by 5 others, said to have been discovered more than a century since in Germany. All the Letters to Brutus are of dates subsequent to the Death of Caesar— In this correspondence, there is much diversity, and even opposition of opinion between the parties— The disposition of Brutus was inclined more to clemency towards the connections of the adverse party than that of Cicero. Brutus was for sparing the brothers of Mark Antony—and he had a sharp controversy with Cicero for the Sons of Lepidus, whose wife was Sister to Brutus. On this point Cicero reluctantly gave way. But the great dissension between them was on account of the honours which Cicero concurred in showering upon Octavius Caesar; and especially upon a passage of a Letter from Cicero to Octavius, in which he intreated him to save the lives of the Assassins of Julius Caesar. There is a Letter of bitter reproach from Brutus to Cicero, and another to Atticus, on this subject— To these there is no direct replies from Cicero; but there are Letters of deep though subdued sensibility, assigning the reasons for his opinions and proposals of measures honorary to Octavius; and most anxiously urging Brutus to come with his own army into Italy, to relieve them from the dependence under which they were upon the legions of Octavius. But Brutus never came, and Cicero was sacrificed by the treachery of Octavius to the brutal revenge of Antony, and Brutus himself fell by his own hand at the fatal field of the Philippi. Plutarch very briefly refers to the compliances of Cicero towards Octavius, by whom he thinks Cicero was deceived; and to these hard complaints of Brutus— I think Cicero was not deceived by Octavius— His policy towards him was compulsory—he considered him, as he was, the forlorn hope of the Republican cause— Octavius was to Cicero, like the bough of the old tree, issuing from the summit of the Rock, in Girard’s Scene of the Deluge— The wife and children hang to the skirts of the husband and father who has swum to the edge of the rock the top of ye which is yet above the encroaching wave— He has seized with convulsive grasp the overhanging bough—the tree is in decay; the bough breaks from the stem out of which it grew, and the family are remanded to the unsparing deep. Cicero was the father of this family, and Octavius was the rotten bough. The last of the Epistles is from Quintus to his brother, written when he was a Candidate for the Office of Consul—very elaborate, and curious as picturing the manner of the times, and the customary arts of canvassing for the chief magistracy of Rome.
27. V. Tuesday.— Sun rose 5:13.

Judge Burnet, and Mr Whittlesey of Ohio introduced three of their friends from that State— A young man by the name of Corbin, came to see me to gratify his curiosity— He said he was a native of Chenango County New-York, but has been keeping school the last six Months at Allentown in Pennsylvania; and is now going to seek his fortune in the Western Country— The day being clear, and the Sun shining bright, I went between 2. and 3. afternoon, to see a Solar microscope exhibited in the Pennsylvania Avenue— Met there Mr Post the Pennsylvania Clergyman. The exhibitor did not well understand his business— The process of crystallization was imperfectly shewn—living animals in a drop of cyder vinegar: and in the dust of cheese. Then legs and wings of flies, bees and wasps— The sting of a wasp—a louse, a flea a moschito and various kinds of wood— The animals have thus magnified a formidable appearance; and the sting of the wasp swollen to the size of a crow bar terminated in a point much sharper than that of a fine cambrick Needle.— I am now reading so many things at once that it produces a painful confusion of mind; and my writing is neglected— I have begun upon the Orations of Cicero— Still labouring upon Sale’s Koran—upon Malthus’s Political Economy; Reviews— Speeches in Congress and Reports of Committees— As illustrative of Cicero’s Epistles I read his life and that of Antony in Plutarch; and now Shakespear’s Antony and Cleopatra of Johnson and Steevens’s Edition, which until lately I never possessed. The notes raise more difficulties than they explain— I never thought Shakespear hard to understand, but I now find him far more unintelligible than Cicero. Many of his thoughts are far-fetched; and many quite unnatural— The character of Cleopatra— The composition of levity of coquetry, of vanity, of female envy and jealousy; of magnificence and ostentation, of cowardice, of affection for Antony and for her children; of cowardice at Actium, and of heroic suicide, rather than be exhibited in the triumph of Octavius Caesar, forms altogether a Portrait, painted first by Plutarch, but which has the glow of Life in Shakespear. The characters of Antony, of Octavius, of Enobarbus, are also well drawn and all from Plutarch— The causes of Peace and War between Octavius and Antony are not very clearly set forth— The time occupied by the Drama, is about ten years—from the death of Fulvia, Antony’s first wife, till that of Cleopatra— The subordinate characters of Enobarbus, of Iras and Charmian—of Soothsayer and even of the Clown who brings the Asps, are true to Nature, and of original humour— The sententious part is not of Shakespear’s best.
28. IV:30: Wednesday.

My wife was very unwell all this day, and great part of it was confined to her bed. In the Evening I had visits from Mr Webster, Mr Silsbee, and the two Lorings from Boston—I commenced the attempt to make an assortment of my pamphlets to disencumber my book-shelves of a superfluous and useless load: to make if possible a Selection from to bind up and render useful—an undertaking which will consume more time than it is worth— It abridged this day much of my reading.
After finishing the Epistles of Cicero, I have taken up his Orations— Passing over those for Quintus and for Roscius of Ameria, which I had read several times, I began with that for Quintus Roscius the Comedian— It is a fragment, broken of at both ends; what remains, leaves it very doubtful whether the justice of the Cause; but it is so spirited and lively, and eloquent that it sharpens the appetite for the remaindor. Fannius Chaerea had a slave named Panurgus to whom Roscius undertook to teach the histrionic art—for which the property of the man was to be in common between them— Some time after Panurgus was killed by a certain Flavius of Tarquinium— Roscius sued Flavius for damages, and received from him by compromise a farm— Fannius claims of Roscius half the Value of the same— Calpurnius Piso, as arbitrator advises Roscius to give Fannius ten thousand Sesterces; on condition that Fannius should if he recovered afterwards any thing from Flavius share it equally with Roscius— Afterwards Fannius sues Roscius at Law, for half the value of his farm, having in the mean time recovered of Flavius a hundred thousand Sesterces of which he had given no part to Roscius— This fact however appears to be denied by Fannius, and there was no record of the judgment— Cicero has the testimony of Cluvius, himself the judge, and that of two Senators who had heard Cluvius speak of the judgment—and yet the fact is argued earnestly by Cicero upon this testimony. In this as in many others of the Orations, the direct address of the Speaker to the adverse party has a rousing and startling effect— He established a dialogue, both parts of which are performed by himself—an alternation of keen enquiry and assumed answers, which carry the hearer along with him as to irresistible conclusions. He is extremely severe upon Fannius, and taunts him even upon his personal appearance— There is much account of money, in this Oration, and I wanted in reading it a Treatise de renummaria— There are several fine moral maxims; and though altogether a private cause, if we had it entire, I think it would be equal to any one of the collection except that for Archias.
29. V. Thursday— Sun rose 5:10.

Dr Harwood comes from Baltimore, and I had seen him there; though I had now no distinct recollection of his person. He talked of political Affairs, and said that the opponents of the present Administration had determined at Baltimore, to recover their ascendancy in the State of Maryland— That they had a few days since had a Meeting and chosen a Committee of forty members who were to take the necessary measures. He said they knew how the State had been lost last Fall, and knew how to recover it now: and that he had spoken yesterday for several thousand copies of Mr Holmes’s speech which he made yesterday in the Senate upon the removing power— This Speech was not answered; but silently voted down— And thus the War of pamphlets and hand bills, and newspapers is about to recommence— I received this Morning, I know not from whom two Copies of a pamphlet just printed at Richmond; being a republication of papers under the signature of Algernon Sidney, and some others printed in the Richmond Enquirer, at the Time of Seminole War Controversy in 1818 and 1819. Two of the Letters are addressed to me, and are violent attacks upon me for defending General Jackson’s proceedings on that occasion— There are also some Comments of the Editor of the Enquirer, in the same tone— They are now reprinted, as a three edged sword against General Jackson,
against me, and against the Editor of the Richmond Enquirer, then the bitterest reviler, and now the most obsequious took of Jackson— The writer of Algernon Sidney is Benjamin Watkins Leigh, a Lawyer of Note living at Richmond— He treats the whole subject like a lawyer, and a mere lawyer— That is upon a contracted scale— The Letters contain a strong Lawyer’s argument, upon transactions of which Indian Savages and Spanish perfidies, and British Incendiaries were the Elements— Scruples of Law and Constitution with such enemies, are like the scruples of the Jews, butchered by their enemies, rather than violate the Sabbath by self-defence— I read the Divination of Cicero against Caecilius— The Question was which of the two should be appointed by the Judges Prosecutor of Verres—Caecilius had been Quaestor in Sicily under Verres as Praetor, and pretended to have been wronged by him— Cicero treats him very roughly both on the score of Talent and of Integrity— He argues that Caecilius is in collusion with Verres—and that the relations between the Quaestor and Praetor were too confidential— There is also much threatening of the Judges, and unequivocal intimations that if they preferred Caecilius, they should be prosecuted for bribery. Hortensius defended Verres; and as he was designated Consul for the next year: Cicero was more afraid of his official power than of his eloquence— He hardly treats him with respect
30. IV:15. Friday.

This is the anniversary of the most calamitous day of my life—that of the loss of my beloved and lamented Son. I passed it in deep humiliation and great depression of Spirit— His most affectionate mother suffering also with many tears— Her brother, and Mrs Smith her Sister, dined and spent great part of the day with us; and towards evening I took a ride with my Son John. His child was quite unwell, and I found application impossible this Evening— I had in the day answered Letters from Joseph Blunt, and from my Son Charles— With the last I returned an Administration Bond for 3000 dollars which John and I executed as sureties for Charles.

Day. My time is distributed as it has been through the Winter— Rising between 4 and 6. and usually walking round the Capitol Square, before or immediately after Sunrise. Read three Chapters in the Bible—and an average of 15. Sections in Cicero Breakfast between 8 and 9— Read in the Newspapers, chiefly Reports of the debates in Congress two hours— Visitors, writing in this diary, and miscellaneous reading till four P.M. Dine— Two hours at table, or sitting after dinner— Write Letters and read Reviews. Plutarch or Shakespear till ten or eleven— Much dissipation of idleness—particularly since finishing the Chapters on the Russian and Turkish War— The habit of procrastination is yet too strong for my Resolutions— A distrust of my own capacity to accomplish well, that which I have undertaken: above all, a hand over which I lose from day more and more my controul, are fearful draw backs to my hopes and intentions— A deep and absorbing anxiety for the prospects of my children and my own, leave me little composure of mind, and no energy for Action—
